text.text: A Guide to Holloway

Holloway. To some, all it brings to mind is Arsenal FC, a famous prison and a ten lane motorway. Not us though. We know that not only is there no object on earth that can't be bought on Holloway Road, but there are also numerous charming independent spots on quiet, leafy streets perfect for offloading some of that burdensome cash. Those who live here are quietly happy about it being their low-key secret: well this is our exposé.
Best for... doing the healthy thing

tip.text:
Chill a little, chill a lot in this vegetarian café where the chef will whip up some tasty grub before your hungry eyes, while that sexy vegan cake clearly has your name written all of it - whatever your name is.

The menu features a luscious selection of homemade healthy choices - our top picks include a knockout mushroom omelette with tomato salsa and perfectly squishy French toast drizzled in maple syrup. We recommend heading down on a lazy Sunday to shovel down a smashed avo brunch before the regulars lap it all up. The only downfall? We have a soft spot for a boozy brunch, but the Allpress coffee was divine and big up to whoever decided to make the saltshakers out of light bulbs.

text.text: Now that looking after our health/planet is popular, EZ and Moss is the kind of vegetarian café we're always looking to locate with a menu with all manner of homemade healthy choices. How does a knockout mushroom omelette with tomato salsa grab you? Or how about perfectly squishy French toast drizzled in maple syrup? It's cute, wholesome and comes with the type of positive vibe that'll surely rub off on you as you do the leisurely brunch dance.
Best for... a delicious cheap eat

tip.text:
Originality, authenticity and frugality are three big words we fuck with, and Xi’an Impression has them all in spades. It’s a small, BYOB, canteen-style space opposite the Emirates Stadium, pumping out regional street food from the north-west of China. A far cry from the luminous sweet and sour from your local, food here has a distinctly savoury bent, with bitterness and richness countering the numbness you might be feeling from the Sichuan peppercorns.

The star player here is the specialty hand-pulled noodles with chunky beef and special chilli sauce - you'd be mad not to order it; the noodles are fat and chewy and the beef chunky and tender. Be sure to sample some of their other obscure offerings though, just make an effort to avoid anything that you’ve heard of before. Come in a small group and you can eat like a Qing for less than 15 quid.

text.text: What do you know about Xi'an street food? We mean pulled pork Chinese burgers, deep fried dumplings, and bitter smacked cucumbers, all served with a richness and delicacy rarely found in Chinese takeaway joints. But the star player here is their specialty hand-pulled noodles with chunky beef and special chilli sauce - you'd be mad not to order them. Noodles as fat and soft as you've ever had with hella tender beef. Real good food, real nice prices.
Best for... a tropical tipple

tip.text:
This is a colourful gem of a bar on a tropical-cool tip, situated on a stretch of road that's neither tropical nor particularly cool. Within spitting distance of the Emirates Stadium, it's run by three pals (two of them brother and sister), who have created a laid-back neighbourhood bar, ideal for sipping on something strong whilst having a chinwag/gossip/bitch and listening to some records.

Pastel coloured chairs please the eyes, bright cocktails please the tongue and a huge selection of vinyl please those ears; you can even choose what's spinning from their dope collection if you like getting your own way. Factor in a sun-trap beer garden out back, an intimate basement below and the option for Yard Sale pizza delivery and it all adds up to a place we rate highly. A friendly, fun and funky spot to do your thing.

text.text: Next up, an unexpectedly colourful gem of a bar on a tropical-cool tip, situated on a stretch of road that's neither tropical nor particularly cool. Run by bro and sis Andy and Joanna, it's a laid-back neighbourhood bar with pastel coloured chairs pleasing the eyes, bright cocktails pleasing the tongue and a huge selection of vinyl pleasing those ears. A friendly, fun and funky lil' spot to do your thing.
Best for... Paris in N7

tip.text:
La Muse is the kind of classy joint that doesn't have to scream and shout about its capabilities. Instead it subtly whispers, 'we're an intimate Parisian bistro and we know what we're doing', and the locals with any knowledge pack in. You get hit by those Franco-vibes immediately, with stripped-back floorboards, low lighting and vintage French frames creating a chic mood as chefs whip up their tapas from the open kitchen.

The food is real high quality: fresh ingredients in well crafted dishes that include delicious brunch bits (full English, eggs, toasts and buns) and a dinner menu with sharing plates such as sardines on toast, octopus sous-vide and chicken breast, bacon, leek and pea fricassée. Out back is the diamond in the crown: a long sun trap garden that's just made for sippin' on a cappuccino whilst playing chess or getting soppy over a glass of red.

text.text: This is the kind of classy joint that doesn't scream and shout about its capabilities: instead it subtly whispers, 'we're an intimate Parisian-style bistro and we know what we're doing', and the locals with the inside scoop roll in. The Franco-vibes are strong with stripped back woods, low lighting and vintage French frames complimenting tapas-style dishes of the highest quality. Suitable for sippin' a cappuccino in their sun trap garden or getting soppy over a glass of red.
Best for... a pub with some charm

tip.text:
There's a lot to love about The Lamb: a candlelit, atmospheric public house that's been serving Holloway scallys since the 1870s. We like to imagine it doesn't look an awful lot different now as it did then, with bare floorboards, candles dimly lighting up the space and restored vintage furniture along with those swoony original green tiles on the facade. There's something about it; an original charm and capable of getting a little raucous but only in the most friendly of ways.

There are plenty of draught ales and lagers from indie breweries, and whilst they don't do food you can order takeaway from the nearby Dough Life and bistro La Muse. Tuesday nights might just be the best night to sample this spot at its liveliest - when live Irish music fills the air, turning it into a hot house.

text.text: There's a lot to love about The Lamb: a candlelit, atmospheric public house that's been serving Holloway scallys since the 1870s. We like to imagine it doesn't look an awful lot different now as it did then, with bare floorboards, candles moodily lighting up the space and inebriated sorts swaying in the fullness of life. It's got an original charm to it: capable of getting a little raucous but only in the most friendly of ways.
Best for... a pastry and coffee

tip.text:
No, the name has nothing to do with cute peaches (soz to our GCSE French teacher) – péché mignon means ‘weakness,’ which is exactly what you’ll be feeling when you look at the freshly made pastries and baguettes in the window of this cosy and intimate Highbury café/deli.

If you're lucky enough to get a seat at the communal table or in the small garden out back, there’s an array of very high quality sandwiches, croques both monsieur et madame, croissants, quiches, salads and egg dishes (benedict being the most popular). You can wash it all down with some Monmouth coffee from a gleaming Marzocco. There is also plenty of produce on the shelves: artisanal condiments, cheeses and wines from France that you just know is the good shit. Fantastique.

text.text: Péché mignon means ‘weakness,’ which is exactly what you’ll be feeling when you look at the freshly made pastries and baguettes in the window of this cosy and intimate Highbury café/deli. Quality is the theme: in its croissants that come fresh out the oven, baguettes that are rated as the best around, artisanal produce on the shelves and coffee that comes as creamy as is legally allowed. Fantastique.
Best for... unrivalled fried chicken

tip.text:
It might not look like much from the outside - or the inside for that matter - but those in the know in Holloway ends rate SSÄM as one of the best places to get good and full. Their speciality is Korean fried chicken, along with bimbimbaps and kimchi, and they do a couple of variations. Our tip would be the volcano chicken. Actually that's more than a tip, that's an order (unless you're vegan, in which case sorry) - that shit is delicious and must be sampled.

Don't expect much from the decor - it's a small and narrow spot with bare white walls and slightly garish lighting. But that only enhances it's under-the-radar vibe and, when you throw in the fact it's BYOB, it's no surprise that the few tables here get booked up a couple of weeks in advance. Booking is essential.

text.text: It might not look like much from the outside - or the inside for that matter - but this is one of the finest places to get good and full. Their speciality is Korean fried chicken and it comes in a few varieties that is an unsubtle dose of rich comfort. Throw in the fact that it's BYOB and it's no surprise that the few tables here get booked up a couple of weeks in advance.
Best for... a pre-match bite

tip.text:
Piebury Corner is the stuff of local legend. It all began with owners Paul and Nicky, who realised that football fans love nothing more than a warm pie and a cold pint before a match. So they started selling their scrummy pie-based goods from their front garden, before setting up shop round the corner from the ol' Emirates, where they've been cooking-up golden, oozing goodness for Arsenal fans and hipsters trailing down from The Garage ever since.

Play it safe with a meaty staple like chicken, ham and leek; steak and kidney; or ox cheek and venison, or behave with one of the delicious veggie options. Pair that with horseradish mash, minty crushed peas, velvety gravy, a pint of Meantime and a blueberry pie for dessert, and you'll feel like the fattest and happiest cliché on Earth.

text.text: Piebury Corner began when Paul and Nicky realised footie fans actually quite enjoy a warm pie and cold pint before a game. And they've hitched that concept up a few notches with golden, oozing pies stuffed full of chicken, ham and leek; steak and kidney; or ox cheek and venison. Pair that with horseradish mash, minty crushed peas and velvety gravy and you're onto something hot.
Best for... a pint with revolutionary spirit

tip.text:
El Comandante is the answer to that age-old question: what would happen if an amiable Bolivarian enamoured by Che Guevara and Argentine Marxism was left to run a pub on a tranquil side street in Holloway? This is one of London's characterful oddities: a one-room pub with San Miguel on tap; posters and quotes from South American revolutionaries on the walls; and Latin music or R&B playing from the jukebox.

Che actually visited here on his gap year back in 1951, which explains the name but also confirms our suspicions that revolutionaries take gap years too. The owner's independent spirit is really infectious; there’s an above average chance that you’ll come out of here merrily invigorated, having either joined someone else's revolution - or with subversive plans of your own.

text.text: El Comandante is the answer to that age-old question: what would happen if an amiable Bolivarian enamoured by Che Guevara was left to run a pub on a side street in Holloway. This is one of London's real characterful oddities: a one-room pub with San Miguel on tap; posters and quotes from Che on the walls; and feverish Latin jams playing from the jukebox. The owner is a real friendly sort and that seems to emanate into the spirit of this one.
Best for... transporting yourself somewhere hot

tip.text:
We’re all for an endearingly ramshackle market that transports you around the world in 30 stalls, and the Nags Head Market is one such place. It's been around since the 70s, serving the local community with all their needs: be that buying fish or meat, having a trim, repairing their shoes, buying gemstones (?), or having their tarot cards read. And, of course, it does loads of inexpensive street food with Japanese, Korean, Colombian, Indian, Turkish, Chinese and Lebanese cuisines all represented by very affable owners.

It's pretty small and rough around the edges - there's undoubtedly some good stuff to be had here but undoubtedly some strange and useless stuff too. For a cheap eat and a transportive experience, enter this community hub and try your luck.

text.text: We’re all for an endearingly ramshackle market that transports you around the world in 30 stalls, and the Nags Head Market is one such place. It's been around since the 70s, serving the local community with all their needs: be that buying fish or meat, having a trim, repairing their shoes, buying gemstones (?), or having their tarot cards read. And, of course, it does a bunch of inexpensive street food with Japanese, Korean, Colombian, Indian, Turkish, Chinese and Lebanese cuisines all represented by very affable owners.
Best for... spicy noodles

tip.text: Having caused plenty of mouths to water in the pop-up world with her vibrant laksa noodles, Mandy Yin has gone permanent in Holloway with Sambal Shiok. This places takes laksa, Malaysia's national dish of spicy noodle soup, and adds a few twists and thrills to create a delicious, vibrant dish: a shrimpy broth base with fat fried noodles, fried tofu puffs, bean sprouts and then chicken, prawn or veggies on top. It's spicy, tasty, comforting, memorable and those that know their way around the noodle (and we include ourselves in that prestigious group) rate this as the best place to get laksa in town.

text.text: Having caused plenty of mouths to water in the pop-up world with her vibrant laksa noodles, Mandy Yin has taken permanent residence in Holloway with Sambal Shiok. This places takes laksa, Malaysia's national dish of spicy noodle soup, and adds a few twists and thrills to create a delicious, vibrant dish. It's spicy, tasty, comforting, and memorable, and those that know their way around the noodle (and we include ourselves in that prestigious group) rate this as the best place in town to get laksa.
Best for... a pizza pie

tip.text:
Pizzerias are not in short supply in London, but they kinda are in Holloway which explains the popularity of Zia Lucia: a relatively simple operation doing traditional Italian pizzas on a range of interesting doughs. They slow ferment their doughs for 48 hours to get them reeeeallly fermented, creating traditional, charcoal, gluten-free and wholemeal bases to lay the foundations for the fresh, classic ingredients to finish the pie.

The restaurant is a no-frills kinda place which is certainly how we like our pizzerias. We got a little sloppy over their Arianna (mozzarella, fresh sausage, taleggio goat's cheese, pecorino and truffle honey); and the 'nduja on charcoal. Both were decent bites - not mind blowing pizza, but good and tasty and, at around £7-11 for the pleasure, affordable. If you're after an inexpensive meal out with the opportunity to get a little loose on Italian libations, this is a reliable enough shout - just prepare to queue jump.

text.text: Pizzerias are not in short supply in London but they kinda are in Holloway, which explains the popularity of Zia Lucia: a relatively simple operation doing traditional Italian pizzas on a variety of slow-fermented doughs. This isn't mind blowing pizza, but its good and tasty and, at around £7-11 for the pleasure, affordable. If you're after an inexpensive meal out, with the opportunity to get a little loose on Italian libations, this is a reliable enough shout - just be prepared to either queue jump or spend some time standing outside.
